author: Jack Blanchard
title: Margaret Thatcher ignored trusted aide's warning that public viewed her as an uncaring dictator
text:
Margaret Thatcher blindly ignored warnings from her most trusted aide that the public saw her as uncaring, hectoring and bossy.
Downing Street press chief Sir Bernard Ingham sent a brave memo to the Tory PM in 1985 suggesting she showed a more sensitive side, papers reveal.
Setting out her “perceived weaknesses” in bullet points, Sir Bernard highlighted public anger over soaring unemployment, then listed her personal faults.
These included: “A more general insensitivity: a belief that you do not care for people’.”
This was followed by: “A hectoring, strident, bossy, dictatorial personality”.
Getty Images Memo: Sir Bernard revealed how the public saw his boss
In the five-page memo, Sir Bernard had first showered her with praise as a “decisive, strong-minded person” and “the dominant person in British politics”.
He also tried to blame the “male-dominated media” for the fact of her unpopularity.
Historian Chris Collins, of the Margaret Thatcher Archive Trust, said it revealed Sir Bernard’s “biggest effort” to push her towards a more gentle style.
But he said there was little evidence she had taken any notice as she gave a typically uncompromising speech to her party conference in Blackpool that autumn.
Margaret Thatcher Archive Trust/PA Wire In writing: An excerpt from the memo to Thatcher
Other papers released today show Lady Thatcher contemplated a comeback for Cecil Parkinson in 1985 - two years before he returned to the Cabinet.
The married Trade and Industry Secretary stood down in 1983 after his ex-secretary Sara Keays was revealed to be having his child.
Papers setting out the Tories’ proposed new cabinet shows Norman Tebbit’s name crossed out as Trade and Industry Secretary, and “Parkinson” written in.
They also show top aides warned his return would be “a high risk strategy” as further revelations would rebound on the then PM rather than Parkinson.
PA Big fan: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher with Cecil Parkinson
A third document showed Lady Thatcher’s fury at being snubbed over an invitation to the unveiling of a Falklands War memorial.
The guest list was signed off by then-Defence Secretary Michael Heseltine.
According to Mr Collins, she responded “explosively” by scrawling on the letter: “Kindly ask the secretary of state to see me immediately.”
The word “immediately” is underlined twice.
Mr Heseltine sent back an apology reading: “I am satisfied that this matter was not well handled.”
